title: Westad on the Cold War Secondary SAQ

content.description:
“The Cold War did not decide everything, but it influenced most things, and often for the worse: The confrontation helped cement a world dominated by Superpowers, a world in which might and violence . . . were the yardsticks of international relations, and where beliefs tended toward the absolute: Only one’s own system was good. The other system was inherently evil.

Much of the legacy of the Cold War centers on these kinds of absolutes. . . . China is the biggest example, of course, and North Korea the most dreadful one, but dozens of countries, from Vietnam and Cuba to Morocco and Malaysia, have significant elements of the Cold War built into their systems of government. Many regions of the world still live with environmental threats, social divides, or ethnic conflicts stimulated by the last great international system.”

Odd Arne Westad, Norwegian historian, The Cold War: A World History, 2017
content.question:
In your response, be sure to address all parts of the question. Use complete sentences; an outline or bulleted list alone is not acceptable.

Using the excerpt, respond to parts a, b, and c.

Identify ONE historical development that led to the Cold War.

Explain how ONE piece of evidence would support the author’s claim that the Cold War led to ideological conflict.

Explain how ONE piece of evidence would support the author’s argument in the second paragraph that “many regions of the world still live with environmental threats, social divides, or ethnic conflicts” inherited from the Cold War.
